title: Re: haha
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Levelass: How does one produce .ico files?[hr][/quote]
Something like [url=http://www.cursorarts.com/ca_if_d.html]IconForge[/url] (or similar) is what you'll want to use to create .ico files. As Spleen said, BMP renaming works well enough (if you don't want to use a specific icon creation program), but I don't think you're able to use transparent pixels for your icons via that method.

Edit: I forgot to mention, those are some enjoyable looking icons, memsys. Nice work.

title: Re: haha
content: i'm using microangelo toolset 6 to make the icons and of course it's [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-pirate.gif[/img]  ed[url=http://profile.xfire.com/memsys][img]http://miniprofile.xfire.com/bg/bg/type/2/memsys.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: haha
content:
Yes, Microangelo is one of the best icon manipulation programs out there, but unfortunately it's a 30-day trial which is a pain. But it will create .icl files (Icon Libraries) which combine multiple icons into a single file (in the same way as say pifmgr.dll has a bunch of icons in it, or moricons.dll from the win3.1 days.)

I grabbed a few game-related icons some years back that didn't exist at the time and combined them into one of these files. They don't look as good as the ones memsys did, but if you're interested I'll post the file to save someone the hassle of extracting and converting the images themselves:

[img]http://www.shikadi.net/pckf/games_icl.png[/img]

Not all the images are exactly 32x32 which is why some of them look a little distorted - I figured having larger sizes would make things look better for people using larger icons, like 48x48. They were originally for my game editor though, so where possible I was aiming for a 16x16 image I could overlay on top of a folder icon, to represent a game's data files.

I also used Microangelo animator to make a couple of 256-colour animated cursors - one of the Duke3D nuclear symbol spinning around (the one used on the Duke3D main menu), the Shadow Warrior shuriken spinning, and the rotating yin/yang symbol used on the Shadow Warrior main menu. Certainly looks better than an hourglass while you're waiting for Windows to do stuff [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: haha
content:
Interesting, this computer will not use renamed .bmp files; is there any actual difference in .ico and .bmp forats?

And I can't get any new programs, I am not in charge, though I would love some Keen icons.
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: haha
content:
The format should be quite different, at least the headers are entirely different. So it isn't just blind luck that Windows allows (I guess, as someone said that, never tried it myself) both to be used as icons, it's a written feature.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: haha
content:
Yes, the .ICO and .BMP formats are both quite different, but the .CUR format is identical to .ICO (the only difference is .CUR allows you to set a hotspot for the mouse cursor, the hotspot is set to [0,0] for .ico files and is otherwise ignored.)

It is a documented feature that you can use .bmp files as icons, although I don't imagine it would be particularly compatible. The reason it works is because Windows uses both bitmaps and icons internally all over the place (e.g. dialog boxes) so they've become more or less interchangeable. I also recall the formats being very similar apart from the initial header (since the .ico format allows multiple images of different sizes) so .ico files essentially contain multiple .bmp images minus most of the .bmp header.

Of course if you try to use a program that *expects* .ico files and give it a .bmp image you'll run into problems...

title: Re: haha
content:
malv do you still have the image files of that icon library ?
and can you send them to me ?[url=http://profile.xfire.com/memsys][img]http://miniprofile.xfire.com/bg/bg/type/2/memsys.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: haha
content:
I don't have the bare images any more (no point keeping them once you've got an icon library of them) but if you do want the images you can grab the evaluation version of Microangelo and use the Librarian to extract them.

Alternatively any Windows "resource editor" can extract icons from libraries like these, for example Microsoft's Visual Studio (or whatever it's called now.) I used to use Borland C++ 5.0. I recall hearing something about Microsoft's latest IDE being released for free, so you might even be able to use that (but it's certainly not as simple as Microangelo is.)

Anyway, you can download [url=http://www.shikadi.net/pckf/Games.icl]Games.icl[/url] from the screenshot above if you're still interested.

title: Re: haha
content: Alternatively, search on Google for "resource hacker" - it's a great little app that will let you extract bitmaps, icons and more from many different types of files containing them.
